feature.name: daily wage calculator
feature.description: The daily wage calculator is a payroll system component that automatically computes daily pay deductions for employees taking unpaid leave. It calculates the daily pay rate by dividing the employee's total salary (basic salary plus allowances) by the number of actual working days in the month, accounting for public holidays and the organization's leave policy (calendar days or working days). When an unpaid leave request is approved, the system automatically generates and reflects the corresponding pay deduction on the payroll table. This feature ensures accurate and consistent salary reductions based on the specific leave policy framework in use.

source_articles_index.title: How is daily pay calculated
source_articles_index.article_summary: This article explains how daily pay is calculated for unpaid leave deductions. It defines the daily pay formula as Salary Amount (Basic + Allowance) divided by the number of actual working days in the month. The article clarifies that the number of days can be either calendar days (e.g., 30) or working days (e.g., 22) depending on the organization's leave policy, and that public holidays must be deducted from the working days count. It provides a concrete example showing how 2 public holidays would reduce 22 working days to 20 actual working days for calculation purposes. The feature automatically creates and reflects pay deductions on the payroll table upon approval of unpaid leave requests.

source_articles_index.title: Introduction to daily wage calculator
source_articles_index.article_summary: Introduces the Daily Wage Calculator feature that provides flexible and customizable methods for calculating employee daily wage rates. Explains three calculation bases (calendar days, working days, custom days) and salary component selection options. Describes how the feature impacts salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deductions. Details the distinction between calculation methods and emphasizes compliance with regional labor laws, particularly for UAE and KSA.

source_articles_index.title: Salary Proration
source_articles_index.article_summary: This article explains how Super admins can update salary proration settings in the Daily Wage Calculator (DWC) by navigating to Settings > Payroll > Daily wage calculation and selecting calculation bases (custom days, calendar days, or working days). The changes affect all active unpaid payroll amounts and require rejection of existing prorated transactions if the payroll month is open. Salary proration impacts both employee first salary and end-of-service settlement calculations.

job_to_be_done.statement: Calculate and automatically deduct daily pay from employee salaries when unpaid leave is approved, ensuring accurate salary reduction based on the number of actual working or calendar days in the month, with public holidays properly excluded from the calculation.

Provide a flexible and customizable method for calculating daily wages that affects salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deductions, allowing companies to align calculations with their specific policies and regional labor law requirements.

Adjust and calculate an employee's salary proportionally based on the actual days worked, affecting their first salary and end-of-service settlement by selecting appropriate calculation bases (custom days, calendar days, or working days).

procedures.procedure_name: Calculate Daily Pay for Unpaid Leave Deduction
procedures.when_to_use: When an unpaid leave request has been approved and a salary deduction needs to be calculated and applied to the employee's payroll.
steps: Receive and approve an unpaid leave request from an employee
Identify the leave policy type in use (calendar days or working days)
Determine the baseline number of days (e.g., 30 for calendar days, 22 for working days)
Identify all public holidays falling within the month
Subtract the number of public holidays from the baseline days to calculate actual working days
Retrieve the employee's salary amount (basic salary plus allowances)
Apply the formula: Daily Pay = Salary Amount (Basic + Allowance) / Number of Actual Working Days
Automatically generate and reflect the pay deduction on the payroll table

procedures.when_to_use: When setting up or modifying how daily wages are calculated for salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deductions.
steps: Select calculation base: calendar days, working days, or custom days
Choose salary components to include in the calculation

procedures.when_to_use: When adjusting how employee salaries should be prorated based on days worked, or when payroll configuration needs to change calculation methodology
steps: Navigate to Settings > Payroll > Daily wage calculation
Select the required calculation basis: custom days, calendar days, or working days
If payroll month is open with existing prorated salary transactions, reject those transactions first, then save the new proration settings

rules_limitations_constraints.rule: Daily pay is calculated by dividing the total salary amount (basic salary plus allowances) by the number of actual working days in the month. ; The number of days used in the calculation can be either calendar days (e.g., 30 days) if following a calendar days leave policy, or working days (e.g., 22 days) if following a working days leave policy. ; Public holidays falling within the month must be deducted from the working days count to arrive at the actual working days for the calculation denominator. ; The pay deduction is automatically created and associated with the specific unpaid leave request upon approval.

Calendar days calculation uses the actual number of days in each month (e.g., 31 days in January, 28 days in February), which directly affects daily wage rates. ; Working days calculation excludes weekends and public holidays as defined in the company's public holiday calendar. ; Custom days calculation allows payroll table managers to set a fixed number of days according to company policies; most UAE and KSA companies use 30 custom days to comply with local labor law.

Changes to salary proration settings will affect all active (unpaid) amounts in the payroll table immediately upon save ; When payroll month is open and prorated salary transactions have been submitted for one or multiple employees, the Super admin must reject the existing prorated salary transactions before saving new salary proration changes

edge_cases_warnings.edge_case_or_warning: When public holidays fall within the month, they must be explicitly deducted from the working days count. For example, if two days are public holidays and the leave policy is based on 22 working days, the daily pay calculation must use 20 days (22 - 2) as the denominator, not the baseline 22 days. ; The calculation method differs based on the organization's leave policy framework. Organizations using a calendar days policy will have a different denominator than those using a working days policy, which can result in different daily pay rates for the same salary amount.

Monthly variation in calendar days affects daily wage calculations; months with different numbers of days (28, 30, or 31) will produce different daily wage rates when using calendar days calculation method. ; Different calculation methods (calendar days vs. working days vs. custom days) will produce significantly different daily wage rates and impact final salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deduction amounts.

When payroll month is open with active prorated salary transactions, Super admin cannot directly save new proration settings; must first reject existing transactions, then save the changes to apply new calculation methodology
